content: After King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon exiled Jehoiachin son of Jehoiakim, king of Judah, to Babylon along with the officials of Judah and all the craftsmen and artisans, the  gave me this vision. I saw two baskets of figs placed in front of the ’s Temple in Jerusalem.
One basket was filled with fresh, ripe figs, while the other was filled with bad figs that were too rotten to eat.
Then the  said to me, “What do you see, Jeremiah?”I replied, “Figs, some very good and some very bad, too rotten to eat.”
Then the  gave me this message:
“This is what the , the God of Israel, says: The good figs represent the exiles I sent from Judah to the land of the Babylonians.
I will watch over and care for them, and I will bring them back here again. I will build them up and not tear them down. I will plant them and not uproot them.
I will give them hearts that recognize me as the . They will be my people, and I will be their God, for they will return to me wholeheartedly.
“But the bad figs,” the  said, “represent King Zedekiah of Judah, his officials, all the people left in Jerusalem, and those who live in Egypt. I will treat them like bad figs, too rotten to eat.
I will make them an object of horror and a symbol of evil to every nation on earth. They will be disgraced and mocked, taunted and cursed, wherever I scatter them.
And I will send war, famine, and disease until they have vanished from the land of Israel, which I gave to them and their ancestors.”
